'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-08-29 20:00:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks Gary, looks good.'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-08-29 20:55:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-30 00:11:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Always deleting and re-creating the bridge prevents the bridge from being configured (ideally at boot) with a physical interface providing network connectivity. See my in-line comment."}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-08-30 00:21:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-30 03:16:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-30 05:55:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Bob, can you please clarify why this has a -1? I have yet to understand.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-08-30 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

salvatore and I talked about this.  We agree with Bob's comments and are going to rework the patch."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-30 15:21:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

A proposed approach in the inline comment.

Please note that I've tried different approaches as well, but this is the only one which reliably works."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-30 16:08:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Another note on top of the previous comment: a simpler approach, based on the assumption that a bridge for the physical interface is provided by the user, would simplify the process and avoid any change in unstack.sh'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-30 16:25:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

I had just written up my in-line comment basically asking the same question - should the user setup the interface on the bridge (and devstack not delete the bridge) or should devstack take care of all this. I think the former is simpler (for devstack at least). Maybe that's OK for now, especially of the single-node case doesn't require attaching a physical interface to the bridge."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-08-30 17:40:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I tend to lean toward not adding/removing the physical interface automatically.'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-08-30 18:00:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I agree with Dan here about adding/removing the physical interface. It's more than just moving the ip address from one interface to the other. (Assuming the host is using dhcp we would need to kill dhclient running on eth0 and then start it on the bridge interface. I also believe that NetworkManager will restart the dhclient process again on eth0). I vote for figuring this out and adding it to lib/quantum later if this is needed."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-30 20:39:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

So, based on Dan's and Aaron's latest comments, are we agreeing that quantum_setup_ovs_bridge() should:

1) not delete the bridge if it already exists
2) create the bridge if it does not already exist
3) remove ports that match quantum's prefixes

If all three (or at least the 1st two), then the provider patch will be able to use this function as well.

Assuming that's the case, I'm still not clear on whether OVS_PUBLIC_BRIDGE (used by l3_agent) and OVS_DEFAULT_BRIDGE (used by openvswitch for VLANs) should by default be the same bridge."}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-08-30 21:15:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Correct. 

I think it will have to use the same bridge since everything might be on the same physical interface. I haven't tried both of these things together yet though."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-31 00:11:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-31 00:24:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Work In Progress

WIP while we flesh out last details on connection of external bridge to the public network, and verify linux bridge support'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-31 00:26:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/11380/9/check/gate-devstack-merge/1042 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11380/9/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/9897 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-31 01:09:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: (3 inline comments)

See my in-line comments. I'm a bit confused about where this is heading."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-31 01:19:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

I just saw the part about configuring veths to bridge between br-ex and the external network in the commit message. Can you explain why that is needed in typical devstack scenarios, as opposed to simply putting the public IPs on the same bridge that the physical interface is on? commit_message:
Devstack support for Quantum L3 agent

Fixes bug #1036910

Starts the L3 agent for Quantum, if the corresponding service is enabled.
Supports L3 agent with or without namespaces.
Available with openvswitch plugin only at this time.

Change-Id: Ic2dd7a2d32e985c5df0a94eee1ecb602f555cd14

To simplify reviewers' task:
I have simplified the code for policy management by leveraging a new feature in the policy engine.

@register('field') will register a function to be invoked everytime a rule starting with 'field' is found.

In this way we don't have anymore to build long policy expressions and add helper functions for building the rules to match."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-09-09 04:40:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-09-09 04:40:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

I hope this new patch addresses your concerns.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-09-09 04:40:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

seeing an odd issue when I test.  If I run: 

quantum net-list

I see the correct output, including 'ext_net' created by devstack.

But if I then do quantum net-show ext_net, it says it can't find a network with that name, I and I see this in the quantum server logs: 

/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/sqlalchemy/engine/default.py:330: Warning: Truncated incorrect DOUBLE value: '70854eb7-d39c-436c-8d66-1807f86f662b'
  cursor.execute(statement, parameters)

70854eb7-d39c-436c-8d66-1807f86f662b is the UUID associated with ext_net.  

I do try to show the network by UUID, it doesn't find the network either, though it doesn't show the same error.

Note: it seems like the sqlalchemy error may only be printed out the first time this happens after restarting quantum."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-09-09 04:40:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

on minor comments on first pass, will test.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-09-09 04:40:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Looks like this branch needs a rebase and one final minor tweak.  After that I will test again (no major code comment).'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-09-09 04:40:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

note: pretty soon after I wrote the last review, I realized that the same is likely true for the corresponding delete port calls.  Testing confirms this.

The issue in both cases is that the subnets are owned by the admin, not the tenant.  

I'm also tracking one more issue, not sure if its related to this change-set or not yet."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-09-09 04:40:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

sorry, this took me long to review than expected because there seems to be one more issue.  The issue is actually my fault, but would be good if you could fix it here:  the two create_port() calls in l3_db.py related to external gateways and floatingips (but not router interfaces) should be called with context.elevated(), since the subnet is going to be admin owned.  Otherwise, we won't find an IP for an ordinary tenant.  The following patch worked for me: 


diff --git a/quantum/db/l3_db.py b/quantum/db/l3_db.py
index 8c12fa1..9562bbf 100644
--- a/quantum/db/l3_db.py
+++ b/quantum/db/l3_db.py
@@ -193,7 +193,7 @@ class L3_NAT_db_mixin(l3.RouterPluginBase):
         if network_id is not None and (gw_port is None or
                                        gw_port['network_id'] != network_id):
             # Port has no 'tenant-id', as it is hidden from user
-            gw_port = self.create_port(context, {
+            gw_port = self.create_port(context.elevated(), {
                 'port':
                 {'network_id': network_id,
                  'mac_address': attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED,
@@ -493,7 +493,7 @@ class L3_NAT_db_mixin(l3.RouterPluginBase):
         # This external port is never exposed to the tenant.
         # it is used purely for internal system and admin use when
         # managing floating IPs.
-        external_port = self.create_port(context, {
+        external_port = self.create_port(context.elevated(), {
             'port':
             {'network_id': f_net_id,
              'mac_address': attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED,"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-09-09 04:40:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Ok, I have this branch passing all tests with a few additional tweaks.  Patch is too big for gerrit review, so I will email w/explanation.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-09-09 04:40:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (5 inline comments)

responding to comments on behalf of salvatore.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-09-09 04:40:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

All three core reviewers have been +2 at one point or another, and I don't believe there are any outstanding concerns now that we've confirmed that the issue gary was seeing is unrelated and will be handled by a separate patch."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-09-09 04:40:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Policies for external networks

Bug #1042030 , part 2

Also reworks model queries in order to allow plugins and extensions
to augment them as required through hooks.

Change-Id: Ice72fc6d3b1c613d596c037818ed66d7e9ed841d

commit_message:
fix unmounting of LXC containers in the presence of symlinks

When looking up the mount dir in /proc/mounts we need
to canonicalize the path so that symlinks are resolved

Fixes bug: 1046313
Change-Id: Ib2bb8253e9cdfeda3c6ba13e56a0f907518ff558

'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-09-08 14:41:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So this addresses most of bug 1024586,
hence the commit message should say at the bottom:

    Addresses bug: 1024586

However auto partition mapping should only be enabled,
when the 'max_part' option is enabled for the nbd or loop modules. So questions I have are:

Have you max_part set on the nbd module?
Have you tried this with loop also?
Have you tried without max_part set?
Have you considered https://lkml.org/lkml/2012/7/19/264
This last point is the most worrying for me in that
we might be not fully accounting for existing race conditions.

We'd need to document the max_pat option in any case I suppose.

I was considering that the existing code was stable enough
for folsom, and that kpartx avoidance could be tried for grizzly?

thanks!"}, {'account_id': 5434, 'date': '2012-09-08 15:30:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I did not actually address the bug, as to me it implies more or less a refactoring of the mount object.

Given the fact, that with the current code using Ubuntu 12.04/Kernel 3.2 the injection into images with partitions (for example the cirros image) *always* fails, I just tried to make it work in more cases than 'never' without giving up the logic of the object. 

"Better than never" could also be seen as a good reason to add it to Folsom and spare the refactoring for Grizzly. 

Cheers'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-09-08 16:52:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Oh right I forgot about kpartx issue 5 in bug 1024586
So while that bug is "avoid the use of kpartx", this change
really is to "avoid the need for kpartx".

While enabling auto scanning for _loop_ devices might be problematic as per comment 1 in the bug, doing so for nbd is probably catered for by the existing nova code which sleeps until /sys/block/nbd15/pid is present before proceeding to the mapping stage.

So adding this change is a good thing at this stage.
I'd like to capture some of these tricky issues in a comment though. Also I notice if partition = 0 a redundant stat is done for /dev/loop0p0 etc. So how about:

    elif self.partition and os.path.exists(automapped_path):
        # Note auto mapping can be enabled with the 'max_part' option
        # to the nbd or loop kernel modules.  Beware of possible races
        # in the partition scanning for _loop_ devices though
        # (details in bug 1024586), which are currently uncatered for.
        self.mapped_device = automapped_path
        self.mapped = True
        self.automapped = True
    elif self.partition:
        as before'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-09-08 17:50:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 5434, 'date': '2012-09-08 18:06:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-09-08 18:33:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Have device mapping use autocreated device nodes

Newer kernels detect partitions and create device
nodes when an image is opened with qemu-nbd. Calling
kpartx afterwards will always result in failures
and prevent injection of data into the current image.

The fix tries to handle this by detecting if a device
node exists and call kpartx only if needed.

Change-Id: I781158ea94f9f0762140e106dd6a1259017b8a3b

Add cliff prereqs

The real issue is cmd2 not pulling in pyparsing properly on a fresh system.

Change-Id: I9bae29f9a664431d0145ebc5a0cc4caec638d739
